node.title: Meadows to Testify Before Jan. 6 Committee as Other Trump Allies Cite Executive Privilege
node.alt: Former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows will give a deposition before the House committee investigating the U.S. Capitol riot. Above, Meadows leaves the Supreme Court confirmation hearing for Amy Coney Barrett on October 12, 2020.
node.description: Meadows came to an agreement with lawmakers, narrowly avoiding a referral of criminal contempt charges from the House panel.
node.content:
["While other Donald Trump allies have refused to appear before the January 6 investigation committee, former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows has agreed to do so for a deposition before the House panel, committee chair Bennie Thompson confirmed on Tuesday.", "\"Mr. Meadows has been engaging with the Select Committee through his attorney. He has produced records to the committee and will soon appear for an initial deposition,\" Thompson said in the statement. \"The Select Committee expects all witnesses, including Mr. Meadows, to provide all information requested and that the Select Committee is lawfully entitled to receive.\"", "Thompson, a Mississippi Democrat, added, \"The committee will continue to assess his degree of compliance with our subpoena after the deposition.\"", "Meadows was subpoenaed by the committee in September for records and testimony related to the attack on the U.S. Capitol last January.", "After Meadows failed to show up for the original deposition, the committee was considering whether it would refer the former Trump adviser to the Justice Department for criminal contempt charges.", "", "
Former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows will give a deposition before the House committee investigating the U.S. Capitol riot. Above, Meadows leaves the Supreme Court confirmation hearing for Amy Coney Barrett on October 12, 2020.
", "Other notable figures who have defied the committee's subpoenas are citing executive privilege. Meadows, who was serving in the White House on January 6, has a more plausible case to cite that protection, unlike former adviser Steve Bannon, who was not.", "However, Tuesday's announcement indicates that Meadows may comply with the panel and avoid further action from its members for the time being.", "This is a developing story and will be updated as more information becomes available."]
